questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with history of having cardiomyopathy presents to her physician for regular follow-up. She has comfortable breathing with ability to climb one flight of stairs without difficulty. Her routine medications are carvedilol, lisinopril and furosemide. On examination blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits along with normal jugular venous pressure. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Sacubitril inhibits the enzyme neprilysin which degrades atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP).
  • Increased levels of ANP and BNP which antagonize the renin angiotensin aldosterone system.This leads to lower peripheral resistance and increased sodium and urine excretion.
  • Sacubitril is contraindicated in patients taking ACE inhibitors like lisinopril.
  • The major adverse effect of sacubitril is angioedema (facial and throat swelling) related to elevated bradykinin levels.This is a rare but life-threatening adverse effect of sacubitril and also ACE inhibitors. For this reason, sacubitril and ACE inhibitors are never given together.

Option A: Nitroglycerine (by oral or transdermal route) and other nitrates by oral routes are used for prophylaxis of angina attacks.

Nitroglycerine can also be used for treatment of acute LVF by slow intravenous infusion.

Option B: Thiazides are used as first line antihypertensive drugs. These are also used to mobilize the edema fluid in mild to moderate heart failure.

Option D: Combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate has also been shown to decrease the mortality. Other vasodilators do not prolong survival in CHF.

Key takeaway:

  • Sacubitril and ACE inhibitors are never given together because of their overlapping side effects of Angioedema.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset dyspnea. He has previous history of an ischemic cardiomyopathy with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 15%. He recently stopped taking his medications. On examination, Respiratory rate is 30/min and oxygen saturation is 89%. On lung examination, he has bilateral rales with elevated Jugular venous pressure. Low extremities show grade 2 pitting edema. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient has classic findings of acute systolic heart failure.
  • Due to ischemic cardiomyopathy, he has poor left ventricular contractility. He has stopped his medications- a common reason for acute exacerbations of heart failure.
  • He now has evidence of volume overload including pulmonary edema (rales), elevated jugular venous pressure and pitting lower extremity edema.
  • All the answer choices are indicated in a patient with systolic heart failure. However, only furosemide will quickly resolve volume overload.
  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits sodium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of Henle. This produces a vigorous urine output within a few hours of administration.
  • Loop diuretics are the mainstay of therapy for patients in acute congestive heart failure.

Option A, B & C:

All these drugs have a role in the long-term management of systolic heart failure.They reduce the risk of heart failure hospitalizations and mortality. None of them, however, will produce a rapid improvement in volume status.

Key takeaway:

  • Furosemide possesses vasodilatory action which is responsible for the quick relief in LVF and pulmonary edema (used IV). Main use of loop diuretics is to remove the edema fluid in renal, hepatic or cardiac diseases. These can be administered i.v. for prompt relief of acute pulmonary edema (due to vasodilatory action).

questions.text: A 58 year old male patient with congestive heart failure was put on digoxin therapy and had a stable level of digoxin around 1 ng/ml. He was also receiving several other drugs along with digoxin. After few months he presented to emergency department with following features on ECG (shown in the figure below). Now on investigation the plasma level of digoxin is 3.8 ng/ml. Which of the following drug is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
• ECG changes with digoxin may purely indicate a therapeutic effect (such as the ST depression and T wave flattening), while other changes (such as T wave inversion and arrhythmias) indicate toxicity
  • The major ECG effects of cardiac glycosides are PR prolongation and a nonspecific alteration in ventricular repolarization (manifested by depression of the ST segment)

Adverse Effects

  • Nausea, ( Earliest )
  • Disturbances of cognitive function, and
  • Blurred or yellow vision are the usual manifestations.
  • Digitalis-induced arrhythmias.

Precipitated by :

  • Hypoxia (e.g., owing to chronic lung disease),
  • Electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia)

To avoid intoxication, a loading dose of approximately 0.6 to 1 mg digoxin is administered over 24 h.

Measurement of post distribution serum digoxin concentration and adjustment of the daily dose (0.0625-0.5 mg) to maintain concentrations of 0.5 to 2 ng/mL are useful during chronic digoxin therapy

Enzyme inhibitors [ Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indians]

Valproate

Ketoconazole

Cimetidine

Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin

Erythromycin

INH

Key takeaway :

  • Inhibitors of CYP3A4 (clarithromycin, itraconazole, etc.) increase its blood levels of digoxin

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is admitted for the treatment of acute myocardial infarction. She was on digoxin for atrial fibrillation. She also suffers from hypertension, for which she was prescribed an anti-hypertensive medication during her hospital stay. Later she developed dangerous arrhythmia, which were immediately treated. Which of the following anti-hypertensive medication added by her physician that likely increased the effects of digoxin?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazide, a diuretic, is known to cause hypokalemia, a state in which the actions of digoxin can be potentiated to a dangerous level.

  1. Diuretics: cause hypokalemia which increases the risk of digitalis arrhythmias; potassium supplements should be given prophylactically.
  2. Calcium: synergises with digitalis → Precipitates toxicity.
  3. Quinidine: reduces binding of digoxin to tissue proteins as well as its renal and biliary clearance by inhibiting efflux transporter P-glycoprotein → plasma concentration of digoxin is doubled → toxicity can occur.
  • Drugs increase plasma concentration of digoxin
    • Verapamil,
    • Diltiazem,
    • Captopril,
    • Propafenone
    • Amiodarone
  1. Adrenergic drugs: can induce arrhythmias in digitalized patients; both increase ectopic automaticity.
  1. Digoxin absorption may be reduced by metoclopramide, sucralfate, antacids, neomycin, sulfasalazine.
  1. Propranolol, verapamil, diltiazem and disopyramide: may additively depress A-V conduction and oppose positive inotropic action.

Option A : Valsartan causes Hyperkalemia. ( Vs Hypokalemia Precipitate digoxin toxicity.

Option C : Hydralazine lowers blood pressure, but it does not generally cause marked electrolyte disturbances.

Option D : Tadalafil is an agent used for erectile dysfunction.

Key takeaway :

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is known to cause hypokalemia, a state in which the actions of digoxin can be potentiated to a dangerous level.

choices.text: It has a high affinity for angiotensin II receptors
It promotes increased peripheral vascular resistance
It decreases cardiac output and increases afterload
It causes vasodilation and induces natriuresis

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is diagnosed with congestive heart failure (CHF). Her physician has prescribed captopril, a medication proven to reduce her mortality. This agent delivers several benefits to patients with congestive heart failure. Which of the following effects is caused by this drug?
questions.solution:
ACE Inhibitors/Angiotensin Receptor Blockers :

  • These drugs are indicated in all grades of Congestive heart failure unless contra-indicated. These can decrease mortality in CHF.
  • These decrease the mortality via prevention and reversal of cardiac remodeling due to aldosterone (final mediator of remodeling).
  • ACE inhibitors cause both arterial and venodilation in Congestive heart failure patients; reduce afterload as well as preload on heart and improve all haemodynamic parameters.
  • ACE inhibitors reduce episodes of decompensation, myocardial infarction and sudden death.
  • Long term benefits of ACE inhibitors accrue from withdrawal of Angiotensin II mediated ventricular hypertrophy, remodeling, accelerated myocyte apoptosis and fibrosis.
  • Indirect benefits occur due to reduction in sympathetic activation and aldosterone levels. Also causes natriuresis
  • Captopril induced hypotension is a result of decrease in total peripheral resistance. The arterioles dilate and compliance of larger arteries is increased.
  • These drugs decrease mortality in Congestive heart failure
    • Beta Blockers
    • ACE inhibitors
    • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers
    • Aldosterone Antagonists

Option A: ARB Group of drugs like Valsartan block AT -2 Receptors.

Option B: It decreased PVR by Causing Vasodilation.

Option C: it decreases both preload and afterload causing decreased cardiac output.

Key takeaway:

  • ACE inhibitors cause both arteriolar and venodilation in CHF patients; reduce afterload as well as preload on heart and improve all haemodynamic parameters.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman with a history of having dementia accidentally takes multiple doses of her anti-hypertensive medication. She is immediately brought and evaluated in the emergency room and the ECG below is obtained. Which of the following drugs did she most likely take?
questions.solution:
This woman's ECG shows complete AV (3rd degree) heart block.

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker with AV nodal slowing effects. By slowing conduction through the AV node, it may prolong the PR interval and, if taken in excess, cause complete AV block.
  • The most consistent action of verapamil is prolongation of A-V nodal ERP. As a result A-V conduction is markedly slowed (P-R interval increases)
  • Verapamil has negative inotropic action due to interference with Ca2+ mediated excitation-contraction coupling in myocardium.
  • This adverse effect may also occur with beta-blockers which also slow conduction through the AV node.

Option A: Hydralazine is a direct vasodilator. Overdose may cause hypotension but not AV block.

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic. Overdose may cause volume depletion and hypotension but not AV block.

Option C: Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker. Overdose may cause hypotension but not AV block.

Key takeaway :

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker with AV nodal slowing effects. By slowing conduction through the AV node, it may prolong the PR interval and, if taken in excess, cause complete AV block.

questions.text: A 70 year old male having a history of congestive heart failure was undergoing digoxin therapy. He accidently consumed 8-10 tablets of digoxin 0.25 mg. Few hours later, he presented to emergency with a heart rate of 50 bpm and ECG showed evidence of a third-degree AV block. Which of the following is the immediate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
ECG showing evidence of third-degree AV block suggestive of digoxin severe toxicity due to AV nodal block.

Digoxin antibody

  • Digoxin specific antibody is highly effective in reversing cardiotoxicity due to digoxin as well as many other related glycosides.
  • It is nonimmunogenic because it lacks the Fc fragment.
  • Given by i.v. Infusion has markedly improved the survival of seriously digitalis intoxicated patients.

Option B: lignocaine is Drug of choice digitalis induced ventricular arrhythmia.

Option C: Phenytoin is an alternative to lignocaine for digitalis induced ventricular arrhythmia.

Option D: Stable patients of sustained ventricular tachycardia can be treated with drugs and unstable patients with DC cardioversion.However it's Contraindicated in digoxin toxicity.

Key takeaway:

  • Digoxin severe toxicity Causing Third degree AV nodal block is managed with Immediate Digiband Iv Infusion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to medicine OPD with a history of brief episodes of unconsciousness and falling on ground. He is hypertensive with a history of atrial fibrillation. He is presently on captopril, atenolol, aspirin and amiodarone. He presents with the following findings as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of a patient's problem?
questions.solution:
Patient has amiodarone induced photosensitivity (Blue man syndrome)

Adverse effect of amiodarone

Mnemonic [The Periphery of My Lung Liver Cornea is Photosensitive]

  • Thyroid (hypo/hyper) (40% iodine is present in amiodarone)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Myocardial depression
  • Lung fibrosis
  • Liver toxicity
  • Corneal deposits
  • Photosensitivity (Rash on exposure to sun)
  • (Bluish: Blue man syndrome)

Option A: Chronic Silver Toxicity causes permanent bluish gray discoloration of skin and eyes. Here eyes are spared and the patient doesn't have exposure to excess silver.

Option B: lupus pernio is violaceous papules over the nose seen in sarcoidosis.

Option C: Captopril toxicity causes Maculopapular rash.

Key takeaway:

  • Photosensitization and sun burn like skin pigmentation occurs in about 10% patients receiving Amiodarone

questions.text: The figure below shows the effect of a drug on the action potential of the heart as shown by arrow. Which of the following drug is likely to produce this effect on action potential?
questions.solution:
• They are Na+ Channel blockers
  • Decreases Slope of Phase 0 depolarization

ECG:

  • Quinidine increases P-R and Q-T intervals and tends to broaden the QRS
  • Mechanism of action: Quinidine blocks myocardial Na+ channels in the open state-reduces automaticity and rate of 0 phase depolarization in a frequency dependent manner.
  • Prolongation of APD is due to K+ channel block, while lengthening of ERP is caused by its moderate effect on recovery of Na+ and K+ channels.

Key takeaway:

  • Quinidine acts by decreasing the slope of phase 0 (Na+ channel blocking property) as well as increasing the action potential duration (K+ channel blocking property).

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient was admitted to the emergency department for treatment of ventricular tachycardia (as shown in ECG below). He was immediately managed at department level with antiarrhythmic medications and discharged with some other antiarrhythmic medicines. After beginning oral drug therapy, he reports cold intolerance and tiredness all the time. His thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is found to be elevated. Which drug is most likely responsible for this adverse reaction?
questions.solution:
• Drugs that can cause hypothyroidism
    • 131I
    • Iodides
    • Lithium
    • Amiodarone
  • Amiodarone, due to its iodine content it can cause hypothyroidism and, less commonly, hyperthyroidism.
  • Goiter, hypothyroidism and rarely Hyperthyroidism may develop on chronic use.
  • Amiodarone interferes with thyroid function in many ways including inhibition of peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and interaction with thyroid hormone receptors.

Adverse effect of amiodarone

Mnemonic [The Periphery of My Lung Liver Cornea is Photosensitive]

  • Thyroid (hypo/hyper) (40% iodine is present in amiodarone)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Myocardial depression
  • Lung fibrosis
  • Liver toxicity
  • Corneal deposits
  • Photosensitivity (Rash on exposure to sun)
  • (Bluish: Blue man syndrome)

Option A, B & C: All other options are not associated with hypothyroidism.

Key takeaway:

  • Amiodarone, due to its iodine content it can cause hypothyroidism and less commonly, hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to your office with a 5-month history of dry persistent cough. His past medical history includes a recent myocardial infarction (MI), after which he was placed on several medications. He does not have any other disease or history. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for the above given side effect as a patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors commonly cause dry nonproductive cough.

Option B : Nitroglycerin can cause headaches.

Option C : Lovastatin commonly causes liver dysfunction.

Option D : Digoxin can cause arrhythmias

Key takeaway

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors commonly cause dry nonproductive cough.
  • A persistent brassy cough occurs in 10-16% patients within 1-8 weeks, often requires discontinuation of the drug-subsides 4-6 days thereafter.
  • It is not dose related and appears to be caused by inhibition of bradykinin/substance P breakdown in the lungs of susceptible individuals.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was taken to the emergency department because of dizziness and chest discomfort that apparently had been ongoing for over 5 hours. His vital signs were blood pressure 170/100 mm Hg, heart rate 50 bpm, respirations 22/min. Physical examination revealed signs of severe pulmonary congestion, and an electrocardiogram was consistent with an anterior acute myocardial infarction. An immediate therapy was instituted including an intravenous infusion of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
GTN is frequently used during evolving myocardial infarction with the aim of

  • Relieving chest pain,
  • Pulmonary congestion and
  • Limiting the area of necrosis by favourably altering O2 balance in the marginal partially ischaemic zone (a consequence of preload reduction).

Intravenous nitroglycerin is currently recommended for routine use during the first 24 to 48 hours in most patients with myocardial infarction, particularly if they have signs of acute heart failure (impending pulmonary edema) and are hypertensive, as in this case.

Option A: Epinephrine is contraindicated in myocardial infarction because it increases cardiac work and oxygen demand.

Option B: Intravenous β-blockers such as metoprolol given within the first few hours after onset of myocardial infarction improve prognosis by reducing infarct size and incidence of ventricular fibrillation.

In this case, however, they are contraindicated because of bradycardia and the impending pulmonary edema (these patients are dependent on sympathetic activation to increase the heart rate and to maintain blood pressure to vital organs).

Option D: Dihydropyridines such as nifedipine have been uniformly unsuccessful in reducing either mortality or reinfarction in patients with myocardial infarction

Key takeaway:

  • Nitrates are useful by decreasing preload (myocardial work) as well as by increasing coronary flow (dilatation and antagonism of coronary spasm, if present).

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department with an acute myocardial infarction. Six months ago, she suffered from a myocardial infarction and began taking propranolol, aspirin, and lovastatin. Her current medications also included captopril and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. Just few days back she stopped taking all her medications. The abrupt withdrawal from which of the following drugs most likely triggered the recent myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
• Abrupt discontinuation of β-blockers such as propranolol can precipitate myocardial infarction and can increase the risk of sudden death in cardiac patients.
  • The underlying mechanism is unclear, but it is well established that there is enhanced sensitivity to β-adrenoceptor agonists in patients who have undergone long-term treatment with β-blockers, likely due to upregulation of β receptors.
  • Abrupt withdrawal from the β-blocker allows an increased number of receptors to be exposed to norepinephrine.
  • This supersensitivity can be attenuated by tapering the dose of the β-blocker for several weeks before discontinuation.

Option A, C & D: All others options are not associated with rebound effects on discontinuation.

Key takeaway:

  • Withdrawal of propranolol after chronic use should be gradual, otherwise rebound hypertension, worsening of angina and even sudden death can occur.
  • This appears to be due to upregulation of β receptors occurring as a result of long-term reduction in agonist stimulation

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient was brought to the medicine department seeking treatment for his grade 2 pulmonary artery hypertension. His vasoreactive stimulation test is negative. Which of the following is the most preferred initial management of this patient?
questions.solution:
TREATMENT OF IDIOPATHIC PULMONARY HYPERTENSION

  • If the patient responds to intravenous vasodilators (< 5%), then oral calcium channel blockers (including amlodipine, diltiazem, and nifedipine) are the first-line therapy.
  • If these are ineffective or the patient does not respond to vasodilators, then therapy depends on function.

WHO class 1 symptoms: Symptom-free when physically active or resting

Key takeaway:

  • Endothelin receptor antagonist are useful when vaso-reactive test is negative
  • CCB are useful in positive vasoreactivity Test.

questions.text: For which of the following Therapeutic use, prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) is ineffective?
questions.solution:
• For Primary pulmonary hypertension PGI2 analogs (like epoprostenol and treprostinil) are used for treatment of pulmonary hypertension.

PGE1 analogs are used for

  • First trimester abortion (misoprostol)
  • Impotence (alprostadil)
  • Maintenance of the Patency of ductus arteriosus (alprostadil).

SUMMARY OF DRUGS USEFUL IN PULMONARY HYPERTENSION

Key takeaway:

  • For Primary pulmonary hypertension PGI2 analogs (like epoprostenol and treprostinil) are used for treatment of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic acts on the SITE C as shown in the figure below?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of actions of different diuretics agents

Thiazides

Drugs in this group include

  • Chlorthiazide,
  • Hydrochlorthiazide,
  • Benzthiazide,
  • Hydroflumethiazide,
  • Chlorthalidone,
  • Metolazone, and indapamide.

These drugs reach the lumen of nephron by secretion through organic acid

  • Thiazides are moderate efficacy diuretics with low ceiling effect
  • Flat DRC, natriuretic effect does not increase appreciably with increase in dose
  • These drugs tend to reduce GFR, therefore are not indicated in renal failure patients.

Key Takeaway:

  • Thiazides are medium efficacy diuretics with primary site of action in the cortical diluting segment or the early Distal tubule . Here they inhibit Na+-Cl¯ symport at the luminal membrane.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented to emergency with head trauma due to road traffic accident. In hospital, the patient developed seizures. Emergency CT scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Mannitol is a low molecular weight compound used i.v. for the treatment of glaucoma and cerebral edema (drug of choice).

Osmotic Diuretics

They are inert drugs that can cause osmotic diuresis.

Mnemonic [MIGU]

Mannitol,

Isosorbide

Glycerol,

Urea and

Option B: Spironolactone is a weak diuretic and are used only in combination with thiazides or loop diuretics to counteract K+ loss.

These can be used for CHF (decrease mortality), hypertension and cirrhotic edema (diuretic of choice is spironolactone).

Spironolactone can be used for the treatment of hirsutism because of its anti-androgenic action.

Option C: Main use of loop diuretics is to remove the edema fluid in renal, hepatic or cardiac diseases. These can be administered i.v. for prompt relief of acute pulmonary edema.

Option D: Thiazides are used as first line antihypertensive drugs. These are also used to mobilize the edema fluid in mild to moderate heart failure. Paradoxically, these drugs decrease urine output in diabetes insipidus

Key Takeaway:

  • Mannitol is a low molecular weight compound used i.v. for the treatment of glaucoma and cerebral edema (drug of choice).

questions.text: A 26 year old male patient with essential hypertension was started on with some anti-hypertensive medications. Later he presented with ECG CHANGES shown in the image below. Which of the following drug implicated for this adverse reaction?
questions.solution:
• Patient presented with hyperkalemia because of spironolactone therapy [ECG showing tall T waves]

Adverse effects of Spironolactone

  • Drowsiness,
  • Ataxia,
  • Mental confusion,
  • Epigastric
  • Distress and loose motions.

Hormonal side effects

  • Gynaecomastia,
  • Erectile dysfunction or loss of libido in men
  • Breast tenderness or menstrual irregularities in women.

Most serious problem with spironolactone is risk of hyperkalaemia, especially if renal function is inadequate.

Option B&C: Have no effects on potassium levels

Option D: Thiazides can cause hypokalemia as side effect

Key Takeaway:

  • Spironolactone can cause gynaecomastia and impotence. Hyperkalemia, abdominal pain and aggravation of peptic ulcer can also occur. ACE inhibitors and potassium supplements increase the risk of hyperkalemia, if used along with these agents

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with congestive heart failure is noted to be taking furosemide each day. Which of the following is most likely to be found in the serum?
questions.solution:
Furosemide leads to

  • Hypokalemia,
  • Hypomagnesemia, and
  • Metabolic alkylosis (elevated bicarbonate level).

Hypokalaemia

This is the most significant Problem

Degree of hypokalaemia appears to be related to the duration of action of the diuretic; longer acting drugs cause more K+ loss.

The usual manifestations are weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps; cardiac arrhythmias are the serious complications.

Hypokalaemia is less common with standard doses of high ceiling diuretics than with thiazides

Hypokalaemia can be prevented and treated by:

(a) High dietary K+ intake or

(b) Supplements of KCl (24-72 mEq/day) or

(c) Concurrent use of K+ sparing diuretics.

  • Alkalosis may occur with hypokalaemia, because more H+ exchanges with Na+ in DT when less K+ is available for exchange.

Key Takeaway:

  • Adverse Effects of loop diuretics include Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyponatremia, alkalosis, hyperglycemia (C/I in DM), hyperuricemia (C/I in gout) and dyslipidemia

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother. He complains of sharp pain in his flanks, as well as dysuria and frequency. The doctor orders a 24-hour urine calcium test, and the results come back abnormal. After additional work-up, the child is diagnosed with idiopathic hypercalciuria. Which of the following is the common type of medication used for this disorder?
questions.solution:
• Patient was having recurrent calcium stones because of idiopathic hypercalciuria.
  • Thiazide diuretics decrease excretion of calcium and thus can be used for idiopathic hypercalciuria.

Uses of Thiazide diuretics

  1. Edema
    • Thiazides may be used for mild to- moderate cases.
    • They act best in cardiac edema; are less effective in hepatic or renal edema.
    • Thiazides are powerless in the presence of renal failure, but metolazone may still act.
  2. Hypertension
    • Thiazides and related diuretics, especially chlorthalidone and indapamide are one of the first line drugs
  3. Diabetes insipidus
    • Thiazides decrease positive free water clearance and are the only drugs effective in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
  4. Hypercalciuria with recurrent calcium stones in the kidney.
    • Thiazides act by reducing Ca2+ excretion.

Option A : Loop diuretics stimulate tubular calcium excretion and can thus be used to treat hypercalcemia.

Option B & D: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and potassium sparing diuretics do not have a significant impact on net calcium balance.

Key Takeaway:

  • Thiazide diuretics decrease excretion of calcium and thus can be used for idiopathic hypercalciuria.

questions.text: An 87-year-old woman who is taking multiple medications for her congestive heart failure is prescribed gentamicin for diverticulitis by her physician. After a few days of taking the antibiotic, she complains of dizziness and tinnitus. Which of the following is the most implicated medicine she was taking for her heart failure?
questions.solution:
• Ototoxicity, as demonstrated by tinnitus and dizziness, is a common side effect of loop diuretics, especially ethacrynic acid.

This effect is magnified when aminoglycoside antibiotics are added to the regimen.

  • Loop diuretics can cause ototoxicity that manifests as
  • Tinnitus,
  • Hearing impairment,
  • Deafness,
  • Vertigo, and a sense of fullness in the ears.
  • Hearing impairment and deafness are usually, but not always, reversible.
  • Ethacrynic acid appears to induce ototoxicity more often than do other loop diuretics and should be reserved for use only in patients who cannot tolerate other loop diuretics

Drug interactions with Loop diuretics

Option A: Spironolactone can cause gynaecomastia and impotence. Hyperkalemia, abdominal pain and aggravation of peptic ulcer can also occur. ACE inhibitors and potassium supplements increase the risk of hyperkalemia, if used along with these agents.

Option B: Adverse Effects of thiazide diuretics include Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyponatremia, alkalosis, hyperglycemia (C/I in DM), hyperuricemia (C/I in gout) and dyslipidemia

Option C: The most common side effect is headache. Nausea and vomiting may occur. Mannitol is contraindicated in renal insufficiency, acute tubular necrosis, anuria, pulmonary edema; acute left ventricular failure, CHF and cerebral haemorrhage.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ototoxicity is a common side effect of loop diuretics, especially ethacrynic acid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a long history of alcohol abuse is being treated for cirrhosis associated with ascites. Her physician decided to give her amiloride, a diuretic helpful in edema caused by cirrhosis. Which of the following common side effect should be monitored in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia, a potentially life-threatening side effect, should be recognized as a possible result of amiloride use.

Option A : Amiloride causes hyponatremia by natriuresis. ( Not Hypernatremia )

Option B & C : Amiloride doesn't alter Calcium and magnesium value much. Loop diuretics cause hypocalcemia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Hyperkalemia is usually associated with amiloride use. So it can be used in primary hypoaldosteronism.

choices.text: Potentiates carbonic anhydrase in all parts of the body
Increases rate of formation of bicarbonate in the aqueous humor

questions.text: A 57-year-old man develops progressive vision loss with a sensation of pressure behind his eyes. His ophthalmologist diagnoses the patient with glaucoma. To prevent further progression of the disease and to alleviatecurrent symptoms, the physician starts the patient on acetazolamide therapy. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
• Acetazolamide belongs to a class of medications termed carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.
  • These agents reduce bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule.
  • They inhibit carbonic anhydrase in all parts of the body, including the aqueous humor, which makes these agents very useful in the treatment of glaucoma.
  • Acetazolamide inhibits excretion of hydrogen and concomitant sodium uptake.

Option A: Acetazolamide Inhibits carbonic anhydrase in all parts of the body.

Option C: Acetazolamide inhibits excretion of hydrogen and concomitant sodium uptake.

Option D: Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase in all parts of the body, including the aqueous humor, which makes these agents very useful in the treatment of glaucoma.

Key Takeaway:

  • Acetazolamide is a sulfonamide derivative and can result in bone marrow suppression and hypersensitivity Other adverse effects include metabolic acidosis (urinary alkalosis) and hypokalemia

questions.text:
27-year-old woman with a history of high altitude sickness was placed on prophylactic treatment with a diuretic drug prior to going on a hiking trip in the Rocky Mountains. Which of the following urine electrolyte profile is most consistent with this drug treatment?

[Note (+) means increase, (o) means no change & (-) means decrease]
questions.solution:
• Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is the only diuretic used to prevent mountain sickness in people who are at risk for this disorder and have to go to a high altitude.
    • The mechanism of this action may be related to the induction of metabolic acidosis.
    • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors produce urine that is very rich in bicarbonate.
    • Urinary sodium is only slightly increased (the efficacy of the diuretic is low).
    • Urinary K+ excretion is also increased

Urinary electrolyte profile of different diuretic agent

Drug B This urine profile would be caused by osmotic diuretics.

Drug C This urine profile would be caused by thiazide diuretics.

Drug D This urine profile would be caused by loop diuretics.

Drug E This urine profile would be caused by K+-sparing diuretics.

Key Takeaway:

  • Acetazolamide is a sulfonamide derivative and can result in bone marrow suppression and hypersensitivity Other adverse effects include metabolic acidosis (urinary alkalosis) and hypokalemia

questions.text: Based on the mechanism of action depicted in the given below image identify drug A and B?
questions.solution:
Drug A is an aldosterone receptor antagonist like spironolactone and epleronone.

Drug B is an epithelial sodium channel blocker like amiloride or triamterene.


Key Takeaway:

  • Eplerenone acts in the late DT and CD cells to preserve K+.
  • Triamterene reaches the lumen of PT by secretion through an organic base secretory system. By travelling through the lumen, these drugs reach its site of action i.e. late DT and CD.
